newsitem.title: UK: Costume jewellery firm Cabouchon to launch in U.S..
newsitem.headline: Costume jewellery firm Cabouchon to launch in U.S..

text.p: Cabouchon, a glitzy costume jewelry firm, goes public in the United States next week, hoping to repeat its rapid growth in Europe and Japan.
Petra Doring, the German-born socialite who founded the company six years ago, said Wednesday she thought the group would succeed in the U.S. market.
"Initially, to be honest, I was a little bit scared because the U.S. has so much costume jewellery, but when we started our trials we had fantastic success," Doring, 36, said by telephone.

The company, with sales of about 120 million pounds ($200.8 million) last year, operates via a network of individuals -- whom the company calls "consultants" -- who sell directly to friends or run teams of other sellers.
It now operates in 17 countries and currently has 16,000 "consultants" -- including some celebrities and aristocrats -- who earn commissions on what they sell.

The company launches two new jewelry ranges each year with a special theme for each, such as the Russian czars or images of India. It has also recently expanded into accessories such as belts, buckles, watches and ties.
Individual pieces cost between four and 140 pounds (about $7 to $200).
